user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_API_Teardown:
```c
void OS_API_Teardown(void)
{
    /*
     * This should delete any remaining user-created objects/tasks
     */
    OS_DeleteAllObjects();

    /*
     * This should cause the "internal" objects (e.g. console utility task)
     * to exit, and will prevent any new objects from being created.
     */
    OS_ApplicationShutdown(true);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_API_Teardown:
void OS_DeleteAllObjects(void)
{
    uint32 ObjectCount;
    uint32 TryCount;

    /*
     * Note - this is done in a loop because some objects depend on other objects
     * and you will not be able to delete the object until the ref count becomes zero.
     */
    TryCount = 0;
    while (true)
    {
        ObjectCount = 0;
        ++TryCount;

        /* Delete timers and tasks first, as they could be actively using other object types  */
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        /* Then try to delete all other remaining objects of any type */
        OS_ForEachObject(OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        if (ObjectCount == 0 || TryCount > 4)
        {
            break;
        }
        OS_TaskDelay(5);
    }
}
...
void OS_ApplicationShutdown(uint8 flag)
{
    if (flag == true)
    {
        OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState = OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER;
    }

    /*
     * Hook to allow the underlying implementation to do something.
     * Assuming the main task is sitting in OS_IdleLoop(), this implementation
     * should do whatever is needed to wake that task up.
     */
    OS_ApplicationShutdown_Impl();
}
...
void OS_ApplicationShutdown_Impl(void)
{
    /*
     * Raise a signal that is unblocked in OS_IdleLoop(),
     * which should break it out of the sigsuspend() call.
     */
    kill(getpid(), SIGHUP);
}
...
void UT_ExecuteBasicHandler(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const char *FunctionName, UT_HandlerFunc_t DefaultHandler)
{
    /* Check if the test case registered a hook, and use the default if not */
    if (UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER) == NULL && DefaultHandler != NULL)
    {
        UT_SetHandlerFunction(FuncKey, DefaultHandler, NULL);
    }

    UT_DefaultStubImpl(FunctionName, FuncKey, 0, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameters are modified in the provided code fragments. Details:

- OS_API_Teardown(void): has no parameters.

- OS_DeleteAllObjects(void): has no parameters; local variables (ObjectCount, TryCount) are modified, not parameters.

- OS_ApplicationShutdown(uint8 flag): the parameter 'flag' is only read (compared to true) and never assigned to or otherwise modified. Writing to global OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState and calling OS_ApplicationShutdown_Impl() do not modify the parameter itself.

- OS_ApplicationShutdown_Impl(void): has no parameters.

- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const char *FunctionName, UT_HandlerFunc_t DefaultHandler): the parameters are only read (checked against NULL, passed to other functions); there are no assignments to these parameter variables. Passing &ObjectCount to OS_CleanUpObject in OS_DeleteAllObjects is permitted because the pointer parameter itself is not reassigned here — only the object it points to may be modified (which is allowed by Rule 17.8).

Therefore, there are no code fragments in the supplied code that require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (modification of function parameters).
